characters: TOLLER AND MARY AND THE SECRET IN THE GARAGE
TILL MY TROPHIES I LAY DOWN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOLLER, early 40's, a cleric, dressed in a worn black clerical garb like a small town judge, tends the historic cemetery of historic First Reformed Church, upstate New Y his face like a half rubbed away engraving on those tombstones, revealed in degrees of shadow. His angular bo lists to the right, as if resisting weight. He is in Agon And he writes.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER STARTS A JOURNAL
dialogues.text: Still images of First Reformed Church, Snowbridge, New Yo and environs: --A yellow on blue iron historical marker reads: “First Reformed Church, Organized 1752, Built 1765. Occupied 177 New York Provisional Congress. Station in Underground Rai 1845 to 1850. Placed on National Register of Historical Places. State of New York Education Department, 1934.” --A Dutch colonial spired church built on a fieldstone foundation under a low fluorescent sky against a mountain ridge. --Oft painted door jambs, slightly askew. --An ancient churchyard lined with weathered grey and une tombstones. A faded inscription reads: “...in memory of Effie Vei Planck Born 16 of February 1737 and Departed th Life November...”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand writes in a black flecked composition notebook. We hear what the writer writes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have decided to keep a journal. Not in a word program or a digital file, but in longhand, writing every word out so that every inflection of penmanship is recorded, every word chosen, scratched out, revised to set down all my thoughts... In a background an unaccompanied keyboard plays, “Pass Me (O Gentle Savior) .” ..-and the simple events of my day factually and without hiding anything. When writing about oneself, one should show no mercy. Who are you hiding from? God?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Brochures in a pamphlet rack feature an antique photo o the church. “A Short History of Historic First Reformed.” Tours every Tuesday and Thursday at 10 AM. --Hands playing the keyboard. --A framed and faded Continental Army flag “raised at the edifice June 1774” hangs beside two glass covered bullet holes. --"From this spot in March 1855, Calvin Verlander escorte Free People of Color to the Canadian border.”

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I will keep this diary for one year, twelve months and at the end of that time it will be destroyed. Shredded, then burnt. The experiment will be over. “Pass Me Not” draws to a finish. JOHN ELDER, 60, the stee guitarist, steps back and takes a seat. Wider angles reveal the nature of the sanctuary, a functi colonial rectangle lined with white painted pews. High stained glass windows let light in from above. The walls lined with memorial plaques and remembrances. Seven PARISHIONERS stand in the pews. Three single elder worshippers, one middle aged couple and one younger coupl token turnout at best. Reverend Toller, dressed in a collarless cassock, stands the pulpit. He reads from the Heidelberg Catechism:

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: “What is thy only comfort in life and death?” The parishioners, Psalter books in hand, join in the response, their voices a communal mumble:

dialogues.speaker: PARISHONERS
dialogues.text: “That I with body and soul, both in life and death, am not my own but belong unto my faithful Savior Jesus Christ, who with his precious blood hath fully satisfied for all my sins...”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller writes in his journal. His voice plays over the reading of the Catechism:

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: These thoughts and recollections are not so different from those I confide to God every morning, when it is possible, when he is listening...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The congregants shuffle from their pews, wait at the alta for communion. Among them are ESTHER, 40, a well dressed woman and MARY and MICHAEL, a working class couple in the twenties. Michael stands at a distance as Mary awaits the communion cup. An Older Man and Older Woman fill out the group. John Elder assists Toller as he offers the silver communi plate and tray holding bread squares and wine cups. Esther and Toller exchange looks as she accepts the wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..-This journal is a form of speaking, of communication from one to the other, a communication which can be achieved simply and in repose without prostration or abnegation. It is a form of prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller removes his cassock and stole, hangs them in the closet beside an alb (white cassock). Underneath he wears he will always, a worn long sleeve black sweater and blac slacks. John Elder counts out the collection from the offertory, places the bills in a small lock box. The Vestry, like the sanctuary, shows age and use. One bi decor contrasts with the Old New England ambience of the room: a framed poster of the Abundant Life in Christ Chur of Fellowship, a mega church in a rural setting surrounde parking spaces. “We are Spirit-filled ... Non-denominatio «+. Evangelistic ... Welcoming.” A smiling photo of Joel Jeffers, “Head Pastor,” a fit black 60 year-old preacher dark T shirt, invites newcomers to services. Toller stacks the communion plate it on a shelf beside th collection plates.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER
dialogues.text: There is a leak in the men’s restroom.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I fixed it.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER
dialogues.text: I was just there. It’s still leaking. Same place. Under the hot faucet.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Did you check the women’s?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women’s is fine. Do you want me to call the plumber from Abundant Life?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Let me have a go at it again. I don’t like to be always asking Abundant Life for little costs here and there.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER
dialogues.text: They don’t mind. That’s what they’re there for. You are totally within your budget.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Still...

dialogues.speaker: ELDER
dialogues.text: Have you posted the sermon?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I did it this morning. A KNOCK on the door.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes? (beat) Come in. MARY MENSANA, 30, seen during the service, pokes her head into the Vestry. Behind her, MICHAEL MENSANA, 30, sits in pew.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Reverend?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Come in. Mary, right?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Mary Mensana.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Nice to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I wanted to talk... John Elder excuses himself.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER
dialogues.text: I‘'ll be right back. Elder exits, closing the door behind him. Mary is pregna

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I wonder if you could speak with Michael, my husband.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Of course. Ask him to come in.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Not now. He’s got to go to Home Depot and work. He’s filling in.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Mary, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (she sits) I’m worried about him. (he waits) He’s involved with the Green planet movement. (Toller nods) He was in jail in Canada. He got out a couple of weeks ago. He just sits at home. He doesn’t go out. I got him to fill out a temp form for Home Depot, so that’s good.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Are you sure you wouldn’t rather go to Abundant Life? They have a staff of counsellors who are much more exper ienced--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, he won’t see them. He says they are more like a company than a church. He said he’d talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Of course. Tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (nods ) After lunchtime.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I’1l come to you. (she nods) I’1ll need your address. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods again) Can you tell me any more?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He applied for Compassionate Release when he found out. He was at Ft. Providence. They let him out two weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Found out what?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That I was pregnant. (beat) He says it’s wrong to bring a child into this world. (beat) He wants to kill my baby. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 19th Century brick building stands to the rear of First Reformed. Light glows from within. Still life tableaus: --A single bed made with military precision --A shelf of books, “St. Augustine’s Confessions,” “Zen a the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance,” “Remembrance of Thing Past,” “The Seven Story Mountain,” “Living Buddha, Living Christ,” Guidelines for Mystical Prayer”... --A medicine cabinet stacked with over the counter remedi Pepto Bismol, NyQuil, Immodium, Advil, Migrane...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller writes in his journal:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assisted Sunday the youth group at Abundant Life. The young people were so excited, so full of life. They were open, they welcome communion. Maybe I shouldn’t care about whether people like me? Did Jesus worry about being liked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On his rear, he prays at his bedside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller pours himself a glass of scotch, sips it. Toller’s bed, unmade, messy, empty.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I look at the lines I last wrote with disdain. Twelve months? Can I keep up an exercise that long? I read these words and see not truth but pride. CLOSEUP: diary.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I wish I had not used the word pride. But I cannot cross it out. If only I could pray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman walking a dog passes. Toller parks in the drive o modest house, goes to the front door, rings the bell. Mary answers the door, They speak. He enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the house, Toller looks around as he hands Mary hi coat. A framed photo of Mary and Michael side by side han by door.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming. (about photos) Our honeymoon. A bike honeymoon. Michael Mensana joins them. He wears khakis and a checked shirt.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Ireland. They exchange greetings.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming. Would you like some coffee? Toller is concerned about his stomach:

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Yes, but...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I think we have some tea.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: That would be better. Mary heads toward the kitchen as Michael leads Toller int small office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit in the cramped space. The room is filled with b literature and announcements about ecological activism. Comparative graphs and global maps show the projected consequences of global warming: the rise of the oceans, drought, vanishing species, migratory patterns. Michael, uncomfortable, shifts his weight:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know why Mary...

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: No reason to apologize. You've been in Canada?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Ft. Providence. That is in the Mackenzie Delta, way to the north.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Beautiful country, I imagine.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It is. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Mary says things have gotten you down.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: “Things?” You could say that, yes. Mary, tapping on the door, enters with a cup of coffee an another cup of tea. She closes the door behind her. MICHAEL (CONT’D) Mary is pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I noticed. How far along is she?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Twenty weeks. How old are you, Reverend? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Forty-two.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Thirty-five. (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That’s how old our child will be in 2050. Five years older than I am now. You’ll be seventy-seven. Do you know what the world will be like in 2050?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: It’s hard to imagine.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You think? (Toller waits) The world is changing fast. Right in front of us. One third of the natural world has been destroyed in your lifetime. The earth’s temperature will be three degrees centigrade higher. Four is the threshold. Michael hands him a printout resting beside the keyboard:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...“severe, widespread, and irreversible impacts”--when scientists use words like that--the National Center of Atmospheric Research, Lawrence Livermore, the Potsdam Institute... Michael stands, hands Toller reports from various agencie speaks as he walks. A GIF plays on Michael’s computer scr the computer animation displays the mutating planet from to 2050--less green, less ice, more flooding, more drough decade by decade. Toller speaks over:

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He went on for some time like that. By 2050 sea levels two feet higher on the East Coast. Low lying areas underwater across the world. Bangladesh, twenty percent loss of land mass. Central Africa, fifty percent reduction in crops due to drought. The western reservoirs dried up. Climate change refugees. Epidemics. Extreme weather. CLOSEUP of wall map as Toller speaks over. Chart depicts ecological “Nine Planetary Boundaries” which lie between mankind and extinction. Of these four (i.e., “ocean acidification”) have been crossed “beyond the zone of uncertainty.” Three are within the zone of uncertainty, t are as yet undetermined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .-the bad times will begin. From that point everything moves very quickly. The social structure will not bear the stress of multiple crises. Opportunistic diseases. Anarchy. Martial law. The tipping point. This isn’t some distant future. You will live to see this. My children will experience this...unlivability. And the behavior it causes...this... Toller waits until Michael pauses and sits. Michael reali he has begun to repeat himself.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought something could be done. I thought people would listen.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Mary said you would be willing to talk to me?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I respect you. I respect what you've... been through.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Do you have thoughts of harming yourself?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No. Did Mary say that?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: No, she didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m not worried for myself. This world will be what it is. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how can you sanction bringing a girl, for argument’s sake let’s say my child is a girl, a child full of hope and naive belief into a world...when that little girl grows to be a young woman and looks you in the eyes and says, ‘You knew all along, didn’t you?’ What do you say then?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: You say what a father has always said. “I love you without qualification.” Michael responds with a sardonic smile.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There is something growing inside Mary. Something as surely alive as a tree or an endangered species. Something filled with nature’s beauty. You speak of “sanctioning” this birth-- is it really your decision? Do you have that right? What does Mary think? Michael doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is her decision?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: You've told her that? (Michael nods) So it is not about the child. Or about Mary. It is about you and your despair. Your lack of hope. (beat) Throughout history humans have woken up in the dead of night, confronted by blackness. The sense that life is without meaning. The Suffering Unto Death.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: But this is something new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man’s achievements have brought him to a great place where life as we know it may cease in the foreseeable future. That is new. Our powerlessness. The blackness is not. Because we are people of science we like to solve things. We want rational responses. If humankind can’t overcome its immediate interests to ensure its survival, that requires a rational response. And that response is despair. He lets this sit a moment.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you believe there is existence apart from this...? Gestures to indicate the material world.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Before us? After us?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. They continue as Toller speaks over:

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I felt like I was Jacob wrestling all night long with the angel. Fighting in the grasp. Every sentence, every question, every response a mortal struggle. Fighting for existence itself. It was exhilarating. Michael brings us back to the moment:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: «+-Do you believe in martyrdom, Reverend?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I’m not sure what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Saints of God, the early Christians who would not renounce their faith, the missionaries attacked in the jungle--do you believe they died for a purpose?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Every week activists are killed protecting the environment. One hundred and seventeen last year. For their beliefs. Michael points to a photo of a framed middle-aged Brazili couple posing in an Amazonian logging camp. Black ribbon curtains the upper corners.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: José Claudio Ribeiro da Silva and his wife Maria were gunned down in 2011 in the Amazon. They protested free cutting of the rain forest. Dorothy Stang, 2005, a nun from Ohio. What was the purpose of their deaths? In 2010 the IPCC predicted that if dramatic action was not taken by 2015, environmental collapse would be irreversible. Nothing was done. It’s now 2017.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: You said you respected me. What I'd gone through.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: You know my story?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You were a chaplain.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: My father taught at VMI. I encouraged my son to enlist. It was the family tradition. Like his father, his grandfather. Patriotic tradition. My wife was very opposed. But he enlisted against her wishes. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Six months later he was killed in Iraq. There was no moral justification for this conflict. My wife could not live with me after that. Who could blame her? I left the military. Rev Jeffers at Abundant Life Church heard about my situation. They offered me a position at First Reformed. And here I am.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Michael, whatever despair you feel about bringing a child into this world cannot equal the despair of taking a child out of it.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What was his name? Your son?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Joseph.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: The boy thrown in the well.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: And you were able to go on?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: The Old Calvinists used to preach a doctrine called the “Unforgiveable Sin.” You don’t hear about it any more. It was the sin against the Holy Spirit. It was the sin against Hope. The only sin that lies beyond forgiveness. (beat) It comes down to choice. We choose hope or despair. We cannot avoid choosing. We are not free to not decide. It’s what we truly are. Courage is the solution to despair. (beat) Reason offers no answers. We cannot be certain what the future holds. We must choose despite uncertainty. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wisdom is the ability to hold two contradictory thoughts in your mind simultaneously. Hope and despair. A life without despair is a life without hope. Holding those ideas in your head together is life. Itself. Pause. The conversation is winding down. Looks at a lonel liquor bottle:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Are you a drinking man, Reverend? He’s inviting Toller to join him.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: It doesn’t help.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No, I suppose not. Toller finishes the last of his tea.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I’ll stay as long as you need me. There’s no place I need to be.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Can God forgive us? For what we have done to this world?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Who can know the mind of God? Perhaps we are a way station. But we can choose. To live the righteous life, to believe, to forgive. Grace covers us all. Michael looks away. Checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We will speak again. Promise me that. (Michael hesitates) I won’t leave until you promise.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Tomorrow at this time. After lunch. (Michael nods) Are you working tomorrow?  16 17

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I haven't heard.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: So it’s a plan then. Tomorrow at this time.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes. It’s a plan. Toller stands and, unsure what to do, awkwardly embraces Michael. Michael responds. Toller opens the door, exits, closes the door behind him. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow falls on the parsonage. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller writes in his journal by incandescent light. We se some of his words in closeup as he writes them. A glass o scotch rests on the table beside him.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I went over everything that was said, what should have been said, what could have been said differently, what could have been said better. He takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Despair is a form of pride. “I know that nothing can change and I know there is no hope.” Merton wrote about this. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Despair is a development of pride so great that it chooses one’s certitude rather than admit God is more creative than we are. Perhaps it’s better I didn’t say that to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Propping one hand against the wall, Toller urinates into toilet. His urine runs dark brown.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Who am I to talk about pride? Toller kneels at his bedside in prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller sits at the kitchen table. He tears bread from a l eats it. Downs it with a sip of scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller, in his civilian clothes, speaks with a MIDDLE AGE COUPLE and a COLLEGE STUDENT in the snowy church graveyar The guests hold printed pamphlets detailing the history o First Reformed.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: .--completed in 1765 in a style we now call Dutch Colonial by settlers in this region with local field stones and timber, First Reformed took seven years to build. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Vei Plancks were one of the founding families. Effie’s tombstone dates from 1787.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tour continues inside the sanctuary.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: The church was partially rebuilt in 1837 following a fire. This section was preserved. Beside the Continental Army flag, if you look closely, are two bullet holes fired during what was called the Skirmish of Snowbridge.

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN
dialogues.text: Do you still have services?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Oh yes, Sunday services are each week at 10 am. First Reformed is the third oldest church in continuous operation in New York State. In a month we will celebrate our two hundred fiftieth anniversary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand before a breakfront near the entrance. Behind glass are mementoes of church history and souvenirs.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: ...-here are examples of the original church chinaware brought over from the Netherlands. And the first chalice. On the lower shelf are souvenirs which are for sale. Key rings, pens, postcards, caps and T shirts, although we only have the shirts in size S. We’re waiting for more to come in. The College Student reaches for a cap.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Try it on. One size fits all.  24 25 26

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand in the choir loft beside a large pipe organ. T College Student holds a “First Reformed Snowbridge NY” baseball cap.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: The pulpit was donated by William Mercer in 1879. The church organ which unfortunately is not working at this time was manufactured by A.G. Hill in England.

dialogues.speaker: MIDLE-AGED MAN
dialogues.text: Did you hear the one about the Choir Mistress and the Minister?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: No, I haven’t.

dialogues.speaker: MIDLE-AGED MAN
dialogues.text: She chased him around the church and caught him by the organ. The Middle-Aged woman elbows her husband as he laughs. To responds with a polite chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I hadn’t heard that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the church, Toller wishes the group farewell as t thank him. The College Student straightens his new cap as walks. The Middle-Aged Man walks away then steps back to slip a folded bill into Toller’s palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 28 The campus like environs of the Abundant Life in Christ Church of Christian Fellowship: a main Fellowship Hall, several ancillary buildings and acres of parking. A large sign lists the pastoral staff and hours of the services. Welcome.” “Lead Pastor Joel Jeffers.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the main fellowship hall, church workers and volunteers are going about the multiple tasks which keep organization humming. The sound of vacuum cleaners. Sever workers clean the chancel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the choir rehearsal room, Esther leads a group of teens, three boys and three girls of mixed backgrounds, listen as Esther leads on a capella version of “Washed in blood”. “WASHED IN THE BLOOD” “Have you been to Jesus for the cleansing pow’r, Are you washed in the blood of the Lamb?”. The teen choir members, well scrubbed and fresh faces, br with adolescent sexuality. Reverend Toller slips into the room, silently nods to Est and takes a seat. The youth choir joins in on the next verse. A boy in the second row slowly moves his hand behind the back of the attractive girl behind him, letting his fingers, in time the lyrics, until it gently comes to rest above the crack her buttocks. She quickly brushes the boy’s hand away.  29 Toller, touched by the melody and lyrics, cannot help als drawn to the garden of slender thighs, bulging crotches, tight buttocks and pert breasts, each about to flower and bloom.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: Very good. Take five. She walks over to Toller:

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A penny for your thoughts. He snaps out of his reverie:

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Joel wanted me to come by.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: Nothing serious, I hope.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I assume not.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: Want to have lunch?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I’ve got something after, but, well sure, why not?

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: (looking at teens) Remember that?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: When everything was ahead of you.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Try to tell them that.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: See you then. (to choir) “In the garden.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 31 Toller walks down an office CORRIDOR. Voices and phones e from behind closed doors. His phone dings as he passes a young man carrying the hymnals. Toller checks his message “Michael called into work. Wants to reschedule meeting fo tomorrow. Mary.” Toller pockets his phone, enters the open door with the nameplate: “Joel Jeffers, Head Pastor.” INT. JEFFERS’ OUTER OFFICE - DAY 30 Two SECRETARIES sit at computer terminals in the carpeted room. The walls are meticulously hung with awards, commendation and famous photos. It feels like corporate headquarters. The FIRST SECRETARY looks, recognizes him with a smile:

dialogues.speaker: 1ST SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Reverend Toller, go right in. He’s expecting you. Toller nods, enters JEFFERS’ OFFICE. INT. JEFFERS’ OFFICE - DAY 31 JOEL JEFFERS, 60, looks up. Toller enters.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: Rev. Toller. Good, sit down. (to Matt) Matt, make those two changes. Toller and Jeffers sit. Joel Jeffers has a charismatic presence. Fit, caramel-skinned, graying, he wears slacks a blue cardigan.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Need water, anything? (Toller shakes his head) How are things at First Reformed?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Good. Busy. You know how it is. You do one thing, then the next, then it’s Sunday again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to ask about the 250th Reconsecration. It’s right around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Eight weeks.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: How's it coming?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: The invitations are being handled by your office. We don’t have that many seats. Your staff, the Elders and Deacons, ecumenical representatives, the Mayor, the Governor--there’s no overflow room. The sanctuary, that’s it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: We’1l simulcast the ceremony here in the main hall. That’s five thousand seats. Have the reception afterward in the rotunda. Is the organ fixed?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: They're waiting on parts. It’s a bigger deal than they thought.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: Can’t have a reconsecration without an organ. (pantomimes playing organ) “AR Mighty Fortress is Our God.” Do you know Martin Luther wrote that sitting in the outhouse. “A Mighty”... (grunt) “Fortress”... (grunt) “Is our God.”

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I think every seminarian knows that story.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: Can't get the image out of my mind. Every time we play that song I look at the congregation and know everybody is thinking the same thing.  They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Prepared your remarks yet?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: The memorial program comes off the press at the end of the month. We’re working on my address. When we have a draft I want to run it by you. Make sure everything is right. Ed Balq would like to meet with us, have a coffee.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Balgq Industries?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: He thinks this is a real opportunity. An important moment in the history of the church, the county. There’1l be national media.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Wow. Jeffers looks at him. Joel leans forward, strikes a perso note:

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: I mean really. It’s been a while since we've spoken. Even a pastor needs a pastor. We’re overdue for a talk. Just you, me.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: That would be nice.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: You should come around more often. There are so many activities you could help with. The young people really like you. Get out of--what do the kids call it? The museum?  32

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: The souvenir shop. They call it the souvenir shop.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: You're doing a great thing.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Thank you again for the opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: No, we thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 32 Toller and Esther carry trays from the cashier, find seat The walls are hung with posters of inspirational images, quotes and Bible verses. A group of church TEENS passes by, greeting Esther, givin Toller a wary eye. Esther and Toller arrange their plates glasses.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: How was Jeffers?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: He wants me to meet with Ed Balq. (shed lifts her eyebrows) Balgq Industries, Balq Energy, Balq Chicken, Balq Peanuts, Balq whatnots.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: Why? Toller starts to speaks but is stopped by a short coughin fit. He resumes:

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: It’s all about the 250th Reconsecration. Balq wants to make sure he gets proper credit for underwriting it.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: He should. First Reformed would be a parking lot if it wasn’t for him. Did you see the doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made an appointment. There was a holdup with the insurance. The insurance companies make it very hard. Esther is not quite sure this is the exact truth.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: Well, that’s what they do. You need someone to take care of you.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Esther, we tried that. I’m not made for that.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: For what? Love? You’re not made for love?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: My marriage was a failure.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: No marriage can survive the loss of a child.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Esther.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: Is that what you think? That what we did together was a sin? That we trangressed?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I don’t believe that. I’ve seen enough real sin to know the difference. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: (backs off) Okay. I understand. I care about you. I want you to be happy.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I am happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller, wearing his cassock, lifts up a fallen tombstone. This seems not so much a practical task but a personal on form of being.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Some are called for their gregariousness, some are called for their suffering, others are called for their loneliness. They are called by God because through the vessel of communication they can reach out and hold beating hearts in their hands. They are called because of their all consuming knowledge of the emptiness of all things that only can be filled by the presence of Our Savior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP. These words as they are written in his diary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller’s cell phone rings. He sets down the brush, remove his phone from his cassock.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Reverend Toller?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Yes. Mary?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It’s me.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I got your message. About rescheduling.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You must come over. Now.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Is Michael there?  36 37

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, he’s at work. You must come over. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The winter light is fading as Toller pulls into Michael a Mary's driveway. She stands on the front porch. Toller approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Follow me. They walk around the house to the clapboard GARAGE out ba She opens the creaky garage door. They step inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary flips on and overhead bulb. The interior is a collag tools, trash and abandoned projects. Two well maintained aluminum bikes hang on wall racks.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I was looking for some batteries. We were out and I thought there might be some here, you know, Mary works her way through stacks of junk as she reaches far end of the garage where a rectangular wooden box like those used to transport Western rifles is stacked with discarded items.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I put everything back just as I found it. I wanted you to see it just as it was. Mary places the objects atop the box on the concrete floo then opens the box itself. Toller looks inside, not sure what he sees. She lifts the item inside out so that Toller can see it. immediately recognizable from news reports and Hollywood movies.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: An explosive vest.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: A suicide vest. Other elements are here. Batteries, detonators, tubes of jelly. Toller looks closer.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s been working in the garage. He said he was fixing a motor. I didn’t question him. He’s been so lonely lately I was happy he found something that made him happy. Toller furrows his brow. What to say?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Did you have any...?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No. No suspicion. Nothing like this. (looks away) I can’t believe this.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Does Michael have any hint you know about this?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: When does he come back?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Later tonight. After closing. Ten PM.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Okay. I will take this. This cannot remain here. I will dispose of it. Don’t let on. Put everything back the way it was.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Are you going to the police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don’t want that, do you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: It wouldn’t help. It would only make things worse. It does no good to threaten him. Don’t let on you know about this. I will come and see him tomorrow. Somehow tomorrow, in the course of our conversation, I will bring this up.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm so frightened.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I don’t think Michael wants to die. I don’t think he wants to abandon his child. He is in torment. But there is an end to torment. He needs support. Are you afraid of him? (she doesn’t understand) Afraid he might hurt you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I’m afraid for him.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Have other activists been around, called him?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Nobody. He has no friends. He’s been barely sociable.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: You will stand by him?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller, using a plunger, struggles with the toilet. It’s backed up. He takes a bottle of Drano, pours it into the bowl.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Discernment intersects with Christian life at every moment. Listening and waiting for God's wish what action must be taken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller lies fully clothed on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My petty ailments have made me bad tempered. I fight the urge to write down the thoughts which come to my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller is bent over, clutching his stomach.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The desire to pray itself is a type of prayer. How often we ask for genuine experience when all we really want is emotion. My hand shakes as I write these lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP: Clean shot of journal. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 A white “Bissel Music” truck is parked outside the church “Pianos Organs--sales, service, repair, moving.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Bissel REPAIRMEN have opened the pipe organ cover and exposed its inner workings. One sits at the keyboard as t other adjusts the ancient pipes. Familiar sounds of organ notes echo through the church.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I didn’t expect you for another two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST REPAIRMAN
dialogues.text: We got a message from the boss. He said it was a top priority.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND REPAIRMAN
dialogues.text: You are having a big event here?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: It’s the two hundred fiftieth anniversary of the Church. They are expecting a lot of important people. The repairmen seem impressed. The lst Repairman testing, plays the opening notes of “A Mighty Fortress is Our God. Toller smiles. Toller’s cell phone DINGS. He takes out his phone, checks messages. There is a message from Michael: “Meet me at the Westbroo Park Trail. East entrance. The red diamond trail. Come alone.” Toller punches in a phone number. Mary answers.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mary, this is Reverend Toller. Is Michael there?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Do you know where he is?  44 45

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He’s out.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Did he come home last night?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes. He left without saying anything this morning. (beat) Reverend?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He was up during the night. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: THE RED DIAMOND TRAIL
dialogues.text: EXT. WESTBROOK PARK -— DAY 44 Toller exits his Toyota in the parking area by the ice covered pond. Michael's car is parked nearby. Geese scatt as he checks the trail map. He locates the red diamond tr heads that direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking up the wooded path, Toller is soon surrounded by trees and greenery. He might as well be in the wilderness He proceeds along the trail with increasing foreboding.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Michael? Ahead, he sees what he fears: two work boots emerge from underbrush. A shotgun lies nearby. Toller walks beside Michael’s body. He looks to recognize but realizes the body has no head. It has been completely blown off. Just a massive red stain. Stepping further he locates the remains of Michael’s skul  46 47 He takes out his phone and dials 911.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An EMS truck and two police cars sit in the parking area, their lights flashing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The area around Michael’s body has been cordoned off with crime scene tape. Two EMS workers lug a stretcher up the as a crime scene photographer takes pictures. Toller stands beside the local SHERIFF. The Sheriff, hold Michael Mensana’s wallet, looks at the phone text message Toller shows him.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: He had been fighting depression. We were supposed to meet again today. I knew he was in trouble, but I didn’t foresee this.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Were you in touch with the immediate family?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: His wife Mary asked me to meet with him.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Did she know about your text?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: No. But she was concerned. We both were concerned.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Have you notified her?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: I guess that’s where I’m headed.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Can I come along?  48 49

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: (nods ) I knew his father.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: What was he like?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: A businessman. Morbid son of a bitch. I guess it runs in the blood. The Crime Scene Examiner indicates he’s finished, waves forward the stretcher bearers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller and the Sheriff stand on the porch speaking with M Toller holds her as she sobs. After a few more moments the Sheriff excuses himself and walks to his patrol car. Drives off. Toller and Mary step inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller looks around, takes a seat. She returns with his tea, takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Have you told anyone?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: (shakes head) If you find any more...similiar things, just discard them if it’s safe. Bury them, burn them. Michael was troubled but his cause was just. There’s no reason to bring disrepute on that cause. (beat) Are you an activist as well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I share Michael’s beliefs. But I want to live. I want to be a mother. I want to have this child.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Do you have family nearby?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: My sister. She’s in Buffalo.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Have you spoken with your doctor? I’m not sure what medications are permissible during pregnancy but I’m sure he can give you something to relax you, help you sleep. She nods. TOLLER (CONT’D) He’d been in the garage?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: And said nothing?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: This is cut and dried from the police point of view, but it might be good to straighten up his office. Remove his laptop. She stands.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He left a message for you. She walks in Michael’s office, returns with a sealed lett envelope, hands it to him. It’s labeled: “For Reverend Toller” Toller hesitates, then unseals the envelope. The letter reads:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL MENSANA
dialogues.text: Last Will and Testament Instructions for My Internment Toller winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He was absent. He was becoming someone I didn’t know. Even before I was pregnant. He was so full of anger.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I stayed while she called her sister. Her sister was going to drive down. Her parents would come for the final rights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller writes in his journal.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A terrible night. No sooner than I shut my eyes desolation came upon me. What is one’s last thought as you pull the trigger? “There goes my head” or “Jesus watch over me?” Or neither? I’m going to tear these pages out. This journal brings me no peace. It’s self-pity, nothing more. Toller, at his computer, researches “Hanstown, NY.” Micha Will and Testiment lies open beside him. “Hanstown Paint Works and Storage.” He brings up images. A red triangular pollution warning sign stands next a rusting ship. “Groundwater around the site was later found contaminated with arsenic, lead, PCBs.”

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I awoke at three with a cry. It has been five months since I sensed the first warning signs.  51 52 53 54

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller walks the dark path from the Parsonage to the Chur

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I went into the church and fell asleep on a bench. INT. FIRST REFORMED —- SANCTUARY - NIGHT 52 He goes into the SANCTUARY, curls up on a pew bench.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: How easily they talk about prayer those who have never really prayed.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: OLD ROCKIN’ CROSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plexiglas sign: “February 6, 250th Anniversary and Reconsecration Service.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Elder plays the newly repaired pipe organ, starting the opening cords of “Old Rugged Cross.” A smile spreads across his face: “So I’ll cherish the old rugged cross, T my trophies at last I lay down...”

dialogues.speaker: ELDER
dialogues.text: This sounds great. I’m going to have to sharpen my chops for the reconsecration. Do you know what they want to play?  55 56

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Not a clue. Abundant Life is handling the invites and seating. Basically I’m going to introduce Joel, he'll give a little spiel, introduce the Governor, maybe Ed Balq.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER
dialogues.text: Why him?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: It’s sort of his deal, I guess. He’s underwriting everything. He paid for the organ. There’s another music thing I want to talk about. Elder ups the tempo of “Old Rugged Cross.” Soon it’s movi at a be-bopping clip (“Rockin’ Around the Christmas Tree” Toller waves him off with a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Actually, it’s a sad bit of business. The Michael Mensana memorial. The scattering of his ashes. He asked me to arrange it.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER
dialogues.text: He asked you?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: He left a letter. He had some requests. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Abundant Life Church in Christ and Christian Fellowsh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 Toller wanders through the expansive Abundant Life bookst and gift shop. One wall displays Abundant Life publicatio Pastor Joel Jeffers smiling face beams from a wide assort of books, CDs and DVDs. Elsewhere clothes racks are hung Abundant Life hoodies, T-shirts and polos. He steps over to the counter which displays pen sets, wristbands and lanyards. The YOUNG FEMALE CLERK notices h

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Reverend Toller, can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I’ve been meaning to come in. We've run out of First Reformed T-shirts. We have some small sizes, but not the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller sits with ROGER, 27, a muscled youth minister, and group of young people in a CHURCH MEETING ROOM. Roger, in black T shirt, has Bible texts tattooed along his bare ar JASON, 18, offers testimony:

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: ...-Since I made my commitment I have felt the Lord moving in my life. If happiness came in pill size it would have “JC” stamped on it. Continuous release size. I wake up feeling better. My relationships are better. I got a raise last week. I find myself in prayer without even thinking about it. Toller doesn’t know quite how to react. Jason is so clear spouting what he thinks he is supposed to say it’s hard t know where the truth begins.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Thank you, Jason. That’s very inspiring. Praise Jesus. My every breath is a prayer. Thoughts, reactions? After a moment, CYNTHIA, 17, half raises her hand.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes, Cynthia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three months ago my father got laid off. He can’t find any work. Nobody loves the Lord more than my father. He’s always testifying, he volunteers. Did he do something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Reverend Toller from First Reformed is siting in with us today. How do you answer that, Reverend?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: There are some church people, good Christians, who make a connection between godliness and wealth, but that’s not what Jesus teaches. That’s not what He lived. There was no dollar sign on His pulpit. There’s no American flag either. No, Cynthia, your father-- JAKE, an arrogant kid, interjects:

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Christians shouldn’t succeed, that what he means. Christianity is for losers.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: (reprimands ) Jake.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I get tired of “turn the other cheek.” Jesus didn’t turn the other cheek. Why stand for anything? Take prayer out of the schools, give money to people too lazy to work-- and whatever you do, don’t offend the Muslims.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller sips tea with Joel Jeffers in the near empty room. Lunch hour is past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? Honest, Joel. I bring up the poor and the next thing a teenager acts like you just shit on the American flag. Forgive my language.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: Roger told me.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: He’s a good man.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: He said you kept your cool. He admired you for doing that.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Everything is so extreme. There’s no middle ground. Us versus them. We’re right, they’re wrong let’s go to war.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: It's the times. These are frightening times. These kids grow up in a world we can hardly imagine. A sea of pornography from the time they’re ten years old, hyper violent video games, a world without privacy, each kid isolated, communicating through media. A world without hope. Raised on a diet of terrorism, nuclear threats and global warming. You don’t know what it’s like to raise a kid in this--

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I did raise a kid.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean it that way. They’re frightened. They want certainty. Don’t think, follow. They fall prey to extremism. Jihadism is everywhere. (gestures) Even here.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: That’s not the church that called me.  59 60 61

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: Nor me. Our mission is to be inclusive. We are a union of believers. That’s why we have the architecture we do. We must listen, guide, encourage young members to express themselves and not judge them. We must lead by example. (beat) We must be patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend Toller, wearing a clerical collar, white apron a white paper hat, stands next to another volunteer dishing hot lunches to a line of men and women on society’s margi sign reads, “The Free Meal Center. Volunteers and Donatio Support out Efforts.” Esther also works as a volunteer. She’s here because Toll is. She glances at him. He looks away. While doing so, he TIPS a lunch tray into the hands of a PARAPLEGIC WAR VET in a wheel chair. Soup and pork and be spill on the Vet’s lap and onto the floor. The Vet, unkept, bearded, wears military patches on his a jacket. A tiny American flag is fixed to the back of his wheel chair. Toller apologetically kneels down, attempting to right hi mistake. Esther joins bearing a roll of paper towels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A line of cars are parked along a two lane road beside t brackish Kills. A makeshift platform has been erected bes the polluted greenish stream. The Hanstown paint factory, dilapidated, deserted, stands in the distance. A red triangular sign pictures a gas mask above the word “Pollution.” Twenty mourners have assembled for the memorial. For the part they are Michael's friends and fellow activists. Mar there with her parents, her sister and brother-in-law and their young child. As is Esther with her a capella choir group. A MOURNER records with a digital camera, panning from Tol to Mary’s nephew who reacts to the foul smelling creek. John Elder stands at his keyboard. Toller reads from his Bible:

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Then the Lord spoke to Job out of the storm. He said: “Who is this that obscures my plans with words without knowledge? Where were you when I laid the earth’s foundation? Who marked off its dimensions? Who laid its cornerstone while the morning stars sang together and all the angels shouted for joy?”... TIMECUT. Mary stands beside Toller holding a plain urn bearing Michael’s ashes.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These surroundings were chosen by Michael as the repository for his physical remains. I say physical because Michael’s spirt and memories live on with us. As does his mission. Michael cared about this world. Perhaps too much. Suffering does not hold. Is not the last word. Resurrection has sway. He’s gone but not his mission. It lives on within us. Mary will lead family and friends in the spreading of Michael’s ashes as the Abundant Life Youth a capella Choir sings a song chosen by Michael. Esther escorts the four person Youth Choir up the steps o the platform. They wear matching khaki pants and blue pol They arrange themselves, look at Esther. She blows her register whistle, cues them to begin.  62 63 The Youth Choir performs an a capella version of Neil You “Who will stand up?”. Mary followed by immediate family and friends walks to th polluted creek carrying the urn. They take turns distribu the ashes into the foul waters. Beginning with the second version John Elder underscores Youth Choir. The mix of the music, harsh lyrics, barren landscape and solemn occasion creates a surreal tableau.

dialogues.speaker: MEET EDWARD BALQ
dialogues.text: EXT. MILLIE’S PANCAKE HOUSE - DAY 62 An 80's restaurant in a strip mall complex. A black SUV pulls in front. The DRIVER gets out to open t rear door but the door opens before he reaches it. EDWARD BALQ, 65, steps out wearing an off the rack suit and hold a large envelope. Balq checks his watch, speaks to the driver, holds up his phone. The driver nods, gets back in SUV as Balq enters the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balgq is greeted with smiles and hellos. The OWNER shakes hand as he leads Balg to his regular table in the rear. Reverend Toller and Pastor Jeffers, seated together, look as Balq walks over, shakes Joel’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: BALQ
dialogues.text: Sorry I’m late. Got held up.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: You know Reverend Toller.

dialogues.speaker: BALQ
dialogues.text: Just by sight. Ed Balg. Good to meet you. Toller greets him as Ed sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to owner) Bring me a coffee. And the apple pie. (to Toller and Jeffers) The apple pie--I know it’s a cliche. Organic. They make it right here. Local. (beat) I’ve got a surprise for you. Balgq sets his phone on the table top, opens the manila envelope. He extracts two 8x11 softbound books, passes th over:

dialogues.speaker: BALQ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I stopped at the printer on the way over. The cover of the booklet features a 18th Century drawing First Reformed with the title: “First Reformed Church, 17 2015, 250 Years of Faith and Service.”

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: They did a great job. Toller and Jeffers page through the handsome booklet. The are photos from colonial times, the fire of 1837, a lake church picnic, a funeral in the churchyard. On the back c is a picture of Abundant Life and insert photo of Pastor Jeffers.

dialogues.speaker: BALQ
dialogues.text: All the guests at the reconsecration will get a copy. There'll also be a mailing. And of course it will be available in the bookstore. How are the plans coming?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: The organ’s been repaired?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: It sounds better than ever before.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: We've drawn up a seating chart. Jeffers passes the seating chart to Balgq who gives it a once over as a WAITRESS brings his coffee and pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayor Wilson and the Governor will be there. Head of National Association of Evangelicals, representatives from NCC, the Office of the Chaplain. Then of course the people from the business community, the financial community... Toller, paging through the book, comes upon a two page sp picturing all the ministers of First Reformed from coloni times to present and their dates of service.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All those mighty men of God, servants of the cross. Years of service--baptisms, confessions, funerals, sermons. The hours in prayer, the afflictions suffered. Did God give them strength? Did He hear them? Balgq’s phone chimes. He looks at the message, ignores it

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: ...Reverend Toller will introduce me, I’1l introduce the Governor. There will be a song selection. The main choir will perform at Abundant Life--

dialogues.speaker: BALQ
dialogues.text: There won't be anything political will there?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: No, why would there be? Balg picks up a fork, turns to them: He shows It shows Hanstown headline

dialogues.speaker: BALQ
dialogues.text: Do you mind? (they demur) I ask because this was brought to my attention. (unfolds a sheet of paper) It’s a print-out from a website. them a page from the Environmental Action website. a photo of Toller in his clerical robe on the Creek platform as Esther leads the Youth Choir. The reads: “Solemn Memorial for Michael Mensana.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both First Reformed and Abundant Life are mentioned by name. (Pause for effect) This was a political event. Neil Young? Jeffers looks to Toller.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I was respecting the wishes of the deceased and the widow. These were their instructions for the memorial service.

dialogues.speaker: BALQ
dialogues.text: At a toxic waste site with the press in attendance?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: The press was not notified. These are Mensana’s friends.

dialogues.speaker: BALQ
dialogues.text: It was a political act. You and the choir represented the Abundant Life Church. The Hanstown Kills site, by the way, is not even polluted. It was cleaned up with EPA superfunds.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: Hanstown was not--—?

dialogues.speaker: BALQ
dialogues.text: Of course not, but give me some credit. I’m in the energy business. It’s my business to stay informed.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: Sorry. Reverend Toller didn’t understand the implications. They turn to Toller for a response.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Mind if I ask a question?

dialogues.speaker: BALQ
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Will God forgive us? (Balg is confused) Will God forgive us for what we are doing to his creation? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was the question Michael Mensana asked me when I visited him.

dialogues.speaker: BALQ
dialogues.text: There’s a lot of loose talk about environmental change.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: There is a scientific consensus. Ninety-seven percent of the scientific community. The “other” side consists of lobbyists and paid deniers.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The man who says nothing always seems more intelligent. Why couldn’t I just keep silent?

dialogues.speaker: BALQ
dialogues.text: It’s a complicated subject.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: What is the benefit? Cui bono? Setting aside the Biblical call to stewardship, who profits when we soil our own nest? What is to gain?

dialogues.speaker: BALQ
dialogues.text: Could we just agree to keep politics out of the reconsecration service?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: What God wants--

dialogues.speaker: BALQ
dialogues.text: You know the mind of God? He spoke to you personally, told you His plans for earth? (shifts tone) Look, I understand you’re upset. You found the body, correct? Toller nods.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: We were supposed to meet. He texted me the location.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you counseled him, Reverend?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BALQ
dialogues.text: You counseled him. Then he shot himself.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Yes. His point is made.

dialogues.speaker: BALQ
dialogues.text: I think you need to step back, Reverend. Look at your own life before you criticize others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend Toller and Mary, bundled up, bicycle along an idyllic rail trail converted for jogging and cycling. She smiles. Toller downshifts, relaxes. For the moment th seem to have left their cares behind.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mary and I rode the rail line trail. I had not ridden a bicycle I think in twenty years. I was afraid I would fall. It is amazing the simple curative power of exercise. It’s God given. They ride down the crest of a hill and around a turn. Toller smiles for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary watches Toller lift an aluminum bike, place it on t wall rack in the GARAGE.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Thank you again. Michael and I used to cycle twice a week. I missed it so much.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: It’s been a long time. I enjoyed it. But it was under protest.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Because? (indicates her stomach) I asked my doctor.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Just the same.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Can I ask another favor?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Would you box up Michael’s clothes? Or find someone to do it?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Are you sure you want to give them away so quickly?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Not give it away. Just box them up. It just so difficult to be surrounded by all those smells. Memories.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I can do it. He looks at where the vest was hidden as he closes the ga door. They walk to the house.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you decided?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: The rent is paid for two months so there’s no hurry. I’11l move in with my sister and brother-in-law until the baby is born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll relocate there?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. She’s already contacted an obstetrician.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: A boy or a girl?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: My next visit I‘'11 find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They step inside the living room. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Something I’ve been meaning to ask, if it isn’t too painful. (she nods) Do you think he would have really harmed someone?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He'd been involved in non violent protests, we both had, he’d been put in jail. He could lose his temper, start yelling at the police. But no, I don’t think he was violent.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I just wonder if I should have done something differently.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He did not want to live. (Toller nods) He was not a religious man, you know. He didn’t care for the church. That was me. I was the one who asked him to come. I was raised in the church and I’ve never been able to quite let it go. When I’m in a strange city I'll just go ina church and sit down. I was the spiritual one.  67

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I’1ll get some boxes. Come back later to take care of the clothes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Before you go, would you pray with me? He appears uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I find it difficult to do alone. The words don’t come. Are you uncomfortable with me asking that?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: No. Of course not. He clasps his hands, lowers his head. She follows suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller writes in his journal:

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I spoke and the words came out of my mouth. “By thy words you shall be justified and by thy words you shall be condemned.” TIMECUT. Toller goes through the boxes brought back from Michael’s garage. The explosive vest is in a box to the s He looks through the file boxes. Michael’s framed photo o José Claudio Ribeiro da Silva and Maria do Espirito Santo rests on the counter. Toller sips a drink of scotch, grimaces. He removes a ser of paperbacks with dire titles: “Our Once and Future Plan “Plants at the Margin,” “Earth under Fire.” TIMECUT. Toller boots up Michael’s laptop. A series of ic and documents appear on screen. He examines the files: Th Fragile Planet. Top 100 Polluters.  68 Environmental Deregulation. Timelines. Bhopal. Marcal Riv Arctic Melt. Ghana. Security Precautions. UN Resolutions. Scientific Associations. An encyclopedic reservoir of research. Toller clicks the “Top 100 Polluters” file. A number list appears: Monsanto. Shell. Kohle. Conoco. Balq. He opens the folder. The first document is a Balq Industr Quarterly Report. He opens it. A smiling photo of Edward accompanies a welcoming message. A menu appears on screen under the title “BALQ” with subcategories: “Domestic Divisions, International Partner Shell Companies, Political Contributions (est), Political Action Groups, Charitable Contributions, Litigations, EPA IEC reports.” Toller takes another drink.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I can no longer ignore my health. I have postponed my checkup too often. Yesterday I literally could barely stand. He clicks through the entries. It’s a chilling progressio Balg Energy, through its partners and shell companies, is under investigation on four continents. Balq is an equal opportunity polluter.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No. I have not lost my faith. He clicks on the Balg sub category “Charitable Contributions.” There it is, between the ballet and the nature conservancy, the Abundant Life Church in Christ an Christian Fellowship. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller kneels by the new Plexiglas church sign beside a b of plastic letters. He places the black letters one by one on the rack, spell out the message:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the rear of the parsonage, John Elder goes through the trash, separating the glass, plastic and metal recyclable He cannot help but notice as he drops bottles into the bi One empty bottle of scotch after another. Followed by an empty bourbon bottle. EXT./INT. TOLLER’S CAR - INNER CITY - DAY (OMIT) 70

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls his Toyota pulls into the parking structure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONTAGE of shots from a physical examination: --a scale is adjusted to record Toller’s weight --a DOCTOR takes his temperature --blood pressure taken --The Doctor taps his back --urine collected --blood drawn --chest x-ray cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday morning. Tableaus of FIRST REFORMED. “Will God For Us?” The sound of the organ comes from within.  74

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten worshipers are assembled in the SANCTUARY. Mary, wear a smart coat, sits alone. Reverend Toller, sitting in the first pew, takes an antia from his pocket, slips it in his mouth. TIMECUT. Toller, at the pulpit, reads from the lectern Bi

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: “,..and he said I will pull down my barns, and build greater and I will say to my soul, take thine ease, eat, drink, and be merry. But God said unto him, Thou fool, this night thy soul shall be required of thee. So is he that layeth up treasure for himself, and is not rich toward God. And he said unto his disciples, Take no thought for your life, what ye shall eat; neither for the body, what ye shall put on. The life is more than meat, and the body is more than raiment.” TIMECUT. John Elder speaks with Esther as they straighten Psalters.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER
dialogues.text: He was out most of Friday.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: He went to Albany? For his checkup?

dialogues.speaker: ELDER
dialogues.text: I kind of asked him but he didn’t volunteer anything. You know how he is.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: Perhaps I can check.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER
dialogues.text: Esther.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: It’s just that...

dialogues.speaker: ELDER
dialogues.text: I know.  75 76 They reach the front of the church. The door outside is o Through the door Esther sees Toller speaking with Mary. H smiling. She is stung by jealousy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grey morning.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 75 76 Toller sits opposite a white coated DOCTOR. Toller’s x-ra are on a computer screen.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: We like to do a gastroscopic exam. We lower a fiber optic camera down the throat and esophagus and take a look around. It’s an outpatient procedure with local anesthetic. You should be able to leave by mid afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: That doesn’t sound good.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: We want to check for evidence of malignancy.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Cancer.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: It’s a possibility. Cancer is not the fearsome medical foe it once was.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: What is the treatment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It depends on how advanced the tumor is. You stated that you have been experiencing discomfort? (checks records) Six months? (Toller nods) Diet, medication, chemo, even surgery. We have a variety of diagnostic tools. Have you had bloody stools?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: How recently? (no response) I would like to schedule the gastroscopy as soon as possible. We have an open slot the week after next. What is your diet?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I get hungry, I eat.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Do you smoke? (Toller shakes head) Drink?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: In moderation.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: That needs to end. I’m writing a prescription that will help with the stomach pain. I want you to take nutritional supplements. You should put on a little weight. Nutrihelp is a good over the counter supplement. Drink a bottle morning and night. Are you in pain now?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: No. Actually, I feel quite good.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ABUNDANT LIFE
dialogues.text: A snow plow maneuvers through parked cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: State of the art communications hub. Sign on the wall: “B Media Center.” Media center employees sit at high tech work stations. A global Plexiglas map with sparkling lights and lines illustrates the worldwide evangelical partners of the Abundant Life Church. Joel Jeffers, dressed casually, addresses the camera in a SMALL STUDIO. A CAMERA ASSISTANT claps an electronic clapboard saying:

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Joel Jeffers, Daily Devotion number 174, take 2. Pastor Jeffers reads from the Teleprompter:

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERS
dialogues.text: “Refrain from anger and turn from wrath; do not fret--it only leads to evil. Psalm 37:8. We tend to think that a little anxiety and worry are simply an indication of how wise we are yet it’s a much better indication of how wicked we are. Fretting arises from our determination to have our own way. Our Lord never worried and was never anxious, because His purpose was never to accomplish his own plans but to fulfill God's plans...” Esther looks out door, notices Toller walking down the corridor. She says to Mixer:

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: I’ll be back in a bit.  79 80 She rises from her seat, walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esther catches up with him.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: Reverend.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Hello, Esther.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you were coming.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Joel's office wanted to go over the reconsecration program. Has he discussed it with you?

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: (nods ) I‘ll be at First Reformed. Stanley will be with the full choir here. The acoustics will be wonderful. I mean, wonderful. Did you hear from Albany?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: (wary) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: What did they say?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Nothing much. More tests.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: A gastroscopy. How does she know this?

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: And you know this how?  81

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: (gives it up) I called. (explains) I’m worried about you. Toller opens the door to the Prayer Chapel, motions for h to follow. They step into the darkened austere room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the door. He takes her shoulders:

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: I just want--

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I know what you want. I cannot bear your concern, you constant hovering. Your neediness. It’s a constant reminder of my failings and inadequacies. You want something that never was and never will be. She starts to cry. She seeks comfort. He doesn’t offer it

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: Don’t make me do this.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: Don’t you see yourself?

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: You don’t take care of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER
dialogues.text: I despise you. I despise what you bring out in me. Your concerns are petty. You are a stumbling block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toller writes in his journal:

dialogues.speaker: TOLLER, (V.O)
dialogues.text: I suddenly feel much better. I awoke early, clear-headed and immediately set about my daily tasks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
